item.title: Bessent, Kato Did Not Discuss FX Levels at G-7 Meeting, US Says
item.description: US Secretary Scott Bessent and Japanese Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato did not discuss foreign exchange levels during a meeting in Canada, according to a statement from the Treasury Department. The news sent the yen lower.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: Why Trump Wants a $400 Million Airplane Rife With Risks
item.description: President Donald Trump has always had strong opinions about the planes used as Air Force One, from their price to their baby-blue color scheme. Frustrated with the growing costs and delays associated with the Boeing Co.’s development of new presidential jetliners, Trump is turning to an unlikely alternative for his next ride: the Middle Eastern nation of Qatar, which has offered him a luxury Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: President Trump speaks to members of the media on Air Force One while flying to Qatar on May 14.

item.title: Rice Costs Imperil Ishiba After Bragging Minister Quits in Japan
item.description: During Japan’s Edo period, feudal lords were warned that peasant revolts start with rice. Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is finding political survival can still hinge on the price of the staple food.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Eddy Duan

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Stages Another Oval Office Ambush, Lecturing Ramaphosa
item.description: President Cyril Ramaphosa came to the White House looking to persuade President Donald Trump to stop floating the conspiracy theory that there’s a genocide against White people in South Africa. Instead, the man who’d helped negotiate the end of apartheid walked into a trap.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

item.title: Disney Suspends Venezuelan Workers on Supreme Court Ruling
item.description: Walt Disney Co. notified Florida-based employees who are losing temporary legal residency in the US that their jobs would be terminated next month after the Supreme Court ruled Monday that the Trump administration could revoke protections for 350,000 Venezuelans.
item.dc:creator: Fabiola Zerpa

media:content.media:description: Cinderella’s Castle at the Walt Disney Co. Magic Kingdom park in Orlando, Florida. Photographer: David Ryder/Bloomberg

item.title: GOP Tax Bill Impasse Unresolved After Trump Meets With Holdouts
item.description: President Donald Trump met with GOP holdouts on his signature tax bill without resolving hardline conservatives’ objections over the multi-trillion dollar cost of the package.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Akayla Gardner, Ryan Chua, Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and US House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican from Louisiana, arrive for a House Republican caucus meeting at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, May 20, 2025. Party leaders have been frantically negotiating with groups of lawmakers as House Speaker Mike Johnson strives to meet a self-imposed deadline of passing the package through the House before Congress goes on break for Memorial Day at the end of this week. Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Prized Oval Office Visits With Trump Become Perilous Tests of Nerve
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump holds up a printed article from "American Thinker" while accusing South Africa's President Cyril Ramaphosa of state-sanctioned violence against white farmers in South Africa in the Oval Office at the White House on May 21.

item.title: Why Trump Is Good News for Gulf Nations
item.description: On this week’s episode of Trumponomics, we look at how the US president’s recent trip to the region was a big win for Middle East oil states.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: RIYADH, SAUDI ARABIA - MAY 14: U.S. President Donald Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman speak as they arrive during the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) Leaders’ Summit at The Ritz-Carlton on May 14, 2025 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The council addresses regional stability, defense cooperation, and energy policy among Gulf nations. Trump is on a multi-nation tour of the Gulf region focused on expanding economic ties and reinforcing security cooperation with key U.S. allies. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Still Has ‘Long Way to Go’ in the House
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior editor Joe Sobczyk looks at the 11th-hour wrangling over the Republican tax-cut plan. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Joe Sobczyk

item.title: Aid Trucks Enter Gaza for First Time in 80 Days
item.description: Dozens of aid trucks began entering the Gaza Strip for the first time since Israel blocked supplies to the beleaguered territory 80 days ago, according to witnesses and transport companies.
item.dc:creator: Fares Alghoul

media:content.media:description: A truck carrying humanitarian aid for the Gaza Strip enters the Kerem Shalom Crossing in Israel, on May 20.

item.title: Republicans Have a SALT Tax Deal. Who Will Benefit?
item.description: For as long as Americans have paid federal income taxes, they’ve been able to subtract some of what they pay to their state and local governments from their taxable income. This federal deduction for state and local taxes — the SALT deduction, for short — has a big influence on how the tax burden is divided. It tends to help taxpayers in wealthier, more urban states, where sales taxes are higher and real estate costs more.
item.dc:creator: Zach C Cohen

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump and US House Speaker Mike Johnson at the US Capitol on May 21.

item.title: Arnault Urges EU to Hold Constructive Talks With US on Tariffs
item.description: Bernard Arnault urged the European Union to hold constructive talks with the US as the French billionaire questioned the course of current negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Angelina Rascouet

media:content.media:description: Bernard Arnault Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

item.title: Senators Scrutinize Proxy Advisers Over Potential Conflicts
item.description: Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee are probing two top proxy advisory firms over potential political bias and conflicts of interest, in a renewed push to subject the industry to greater oversight.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Beyoud

media:content.media:description: Senator Tim Scott, a Republican from South Carolina and ranking member of the Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee, speaks during a hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Dec. 11, 2024. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is working on a rule that would allow domestic violence and elder abuse victims to expunge "coerced debt" from their credit reports.

item.title: Rubio Signals Labeling Putin War Criminal Would Hurt Peace Talks
item.description: America’s top diplomat signaled that accusing Russia’s President Vladimir Putin of war crimes in Ukraine could undermine President Donald Trump’s efforts to negotiate an end to the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: Marco Rubio testifies before the Senate Appropriations Committee Subcommittee on State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs in the Dirksen Senate Office Building in Washington, DC.

item.title: Malaysia’s Anwar Says US Trade Talks Unaffected by China Ties
item.description: Malaysia’s Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said the US pledged to “sympathetically” review its appeal for lower tariffs even as the Southeast Asian nation seeks to strengthen its ties with Washington’s top competitor China.
item.dc:creator: Netty Idayu Ismail

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim

item.title: G-7 Finance Ministers Aim to Avoid Public Spats With US Despite Trade Turmoil
item.description: Finance ministers who’ve gathered in Canada for a Group of Seven meeting this week face a difficult task — trying to find common ground on trade issues while avoiding public conflict with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Erik Hertzberg, Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Tourists take photos with the Banff town sign, ahead of the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors' Meeting in Banff, Alberta, Canada on May 20, 2025. Top finance leaders from the G7 nations gather in Canada starting Tuesday, with concerns including war in Ukraine at the fore while the advanced economies grapple with fallout from US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs. (Photo by Cole Burston / AFP) (Photo by COLE BURSTON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Rich Argentines Face Higher Energy Bills After Milei Subsidy Cut
item.description: President Javier Milei will cut energy subsidies for all gated communities in the greater Buenos Aires region, a move that will hit a portion of Argentina’s upper class that for years has been paying a fraction of their gas and electric bills.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: A tower under construction next to luxury residential buildings in the Puerto Madero neighborhood of Buenos Aires.

item.title: US Accepts Qatar Luxury Jet as Trump’s New Air Force One
item.description: The Defense Department formally accepted a luxury Boeing Co. 747-8 jumbo jet from Qatar to temporarily serve as the new Air Force One for President Donald Trump, one of the biggest foreign gifts ever given to the US government.
item.dc:creator: Courtney McBride, Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: The Qatari Boeing 747 at Palm Beach International airport after Trump toured the aircraft on Feb. 15.

item.title: Spain, Portugal Urge EU Effort on Power Link After Blackout
item.description: Spain and Portugal have called on the European Union to accelerate the completion of a cross-border power connection with the Iberian Peninsula after a recent blackout highlighted risks for the region’s electricity supply.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: A police officer directs disrupted traffic as traffic lights stopped working during a power outage in Barcelona, Spain, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Spain and Portugal lost power shortly after 12:30 p.m. local time in a massive blackout that idled public transport, airports and phone services, bringing the daily activities of millions to a halt.

item.title: Third CFTC Commissioner to Resign Amid Wave of Departures
item.description: Democratic Commissioner Kristin Johnson plans to step down from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission later this year, the latest of several high-profile departures at the regulator.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Beyoud

media:content.media:description: Kristin Johnson, commissioner at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission

item.title: Moscow Intercepts 18 Drones With Airports Suspending Operations
item.description: Moscow’s mayor said 18 drones had been intercepted flying toward the capital Wednesday as travelers faced disruption at airports that were forced to suspend operations.
item.dc:creator: Deana Kjuka

media:content.media:description: Airline passengers look at flight information screens at Domodedovo Airport in Domodedovo, Russia.

item.title: EU Sends New Trade Proposal to US in Step to Secure Deal
item.description: The European Union has shared a revised trade proposal with the US, as it aims to inject momentum in talks with President Donald Trump’s administration amid lingering skepticism that a transatlantic deal can be reached.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Containers at Trieste Port in Trieste, Italy.

item.title: France’s Lombard Eyes Progress With US at G-7, Even Without a Communique
item.description: France’s finance chief Eric Lombard said the Group of Seven can make progress on resolving differences with the US on divisive issues including trade, even if officials meeting over the next two days fail to deliver a final communique.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: France’s finance chief Eric Lombard, right, meets Canadian Finance Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne during the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors’ Meeting in Banff, Alberta, Canada, on May 21.

item.title: US to Keep China Chip Curbs, Spurning Nvidia’s Call for Relief
item.description: The Trump administration will maintain efforts to keep advanced artificial intelligence technology out of China’s hands, a top White House official said, brushing off calls from Nvidia Corp. Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang to ease restrictions on chip exports to the world’s second largest economy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Shepard, Edward Ludlow

media:content.media:description: Nvidia Corp. chips in Taipei, Taiwan.

item.title: Chicago Suburb Plans to Seize Pope Leo’s Childhood Home
item.description: A Chicago-area town plans to take control of Pope Leo XIV’s childhood home to turn it into a local landmark, just days after the current owner put the property up for auction.
item.dc:creator: Miranda Davis

media:content.media:description: The pope’s childhood home in Dolton, Illinois

item.title: Congresswoman Appears in Court on Assault Case at ICE Facility
item.description: LaMonica McIver, a New Jersey Congresswoman, made a court appearance Wednesday to face felony charges accusing her of assaulting US immigration officers as she tried to prevent the city’s mayor from being arrested outside a private detention facility.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: LaMonica McIver demands the release of Newark Mayor Ras Baraka after his arrest while protesting outside an ICE detention facility in Newark on May 9.

item.title: Why Rising Israel-Iran Tensions Threaten to Boil Over
item.description: The conflict between Israel and Iran has shaped the Middle East for decades. It was largely on a low boil as the two sides attacked each other — mostly quietly and in Iran’s case often by proxy — while avoiding a full-blown war.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Sykes, Ethan Bronner, Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: An anti-Israel billboard in Tehran, on May 5.

item.title: Merz Sees Germany on NATO Path to 5% Goal Defense Spending
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz for the first time publicly advocated spending up to 5% of the German economy on defense.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: Leopard 1A5 main battle tanks destined near Klietz, Germany.

item.title: EU Unveils Plan to Revitalize World’s Second-Biggest Market
item.description: The European Union is seeking to strengthen its common market in the face of rising geopolitical tensions and a growing trade conflict with the US, which is threatening to hit the bloc with wide-ranging tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Crook, Michal Kubala, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: European Commission President Ursula Von der Leyen on May 21.

item.title: US Defends Removing Criminal Migrants Amid South Sudan Confusion
item.description: The US Department of Homeland Security said eight immigrants convicted of serious crimes remain in federal custody following a deportation attempt that sparked confusion over whether they were sent to South Sudan, a country gripped by years of violence.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JUNE 6: An ICE agent monitors hundreds of asylum seekers being processed upon entering the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building on June 6, 2023 in New York City. New York City has provided sanctuary to over 46,000 asylum seekers since 2013, when the city passed a law prohibiting city agencies from cooperating with federal immigration enforcement agencies unless there is a warrant for the person's arrest.(Photo by David Dee Delgado/Getty Images) Photographer: David Dee Delgado/Getty Images North America
